title: 103_hr4432
content: The "Public Housing Regulatory Relief Act" allows for the waiver of public housing program requirements under the United States Housing Act of 1937. The Secretary may authorize public housing agencies to establish policies for the operation, maintenance, and development of public housing projects, with the ability to waive or modify certain requirements under the Act and other laws. The Secretary may authorize public housing agencies to establish policies for the operation, maintenance, and development of public housing projects, with the ability to waive or modify certain requirements under the Act and other laws, including limits on occupancy, replacement of dwelling units, relocation assistance, equal opportunity, nondiscrimination, environment, and labor standards. Requests for waivers must be made in accordance with specified procedures. The Secretary can authorize public housing agencies to waive or modify certain requirements for public housing projects. Requests for waivers must specify the laws to be waived, describe the policies to be implemented, and outline the costs involved. The Secretary can only approve requests that meet minimum criteria. The Secretary can authorize public housing agencies to waive or modify requirements for public housing projects. Requests must meet specific criteria, including not incurring more costs for the government, aligning with the public housing program's goals, and complying with various laws. Any granted authority is effective for a specified period determined by the Secretary. The Secretary can renew authority for public housing agencies or resident management corporations for up to 4 years. State and local laws apply to entities granted authority. Annual reports are required for approved agencies and corporations. The report shall detail the activities, operations, and policies of the agency or corporation during the year. The term 'resident management corporation' refers to a corporation established in accordance with the Secretary's requirements under section 20. PHA retains savings from efficient management. Section 6(e) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to allow public housing agencies to retain savings from efficient management. Excess funds can be used to reduce subsequent annual contributions and establish an operating reserve for low-income housing projects. The United States Housing Act of 1937 allows public housing agencies to retain savings from efficient management to establish an operating reserve for low-income housing projects. This reserve cannot be used in subsequent years to calculate operating subsidies, unless approved in the agency's budget. SEC. 4. Availability of public housing modernization funds during term of plan. Section 14 of the United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to allow public housing agencies flexibility in using assistance amounts for purposes consistent with their plans, without being tied to specific schedules or fiscal years. RECAPTURE OF PUBLIC HOUSING MODERNIZATION FUNDS. Section 14(g) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to allow the Secretary to recapture and redistribute funds provided to public housing agencies. The recaptured amounts will be taken from agencies that have not made reasonable progress in modernization projects, and redistributed to other agencies for use. The Secretary can recapture and redistribute funds from public housing agencies that have not made progress in modernization projects. The redistributed amounts will be used by other agencies in need, based on an allocation system and annual schedule. SEC. 6. AUTHORITY FOR PHA'S TO BORROW AGAINST FUTURE PUBLIC HOUSING MODERNIZATION FUNDS. Section 14 of the United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to allow public housing agencies to enter agreements to use future assistance for repaying financing used for public housing development, rehabilitation, or modernization. The terms of the notes or obligations must meet certain conditions set by the Secretary. The Secretary may not deny a guarantee under this subsection based on the proposed repayment period, unless it exceeds 30 years or poses an unacceptable financial risk. Assistance cannot be pledged for repayment if the total outstanding principal exceeds 5 times the assistance provided in the most recent fiscal year. Repayment terms are subject to certain conditions. Assistance provided under this section can be used to pay principal and interest on obligations issued by the public housing agency. SEC. 7. STUDY OF ACQUISITION AND LABOR REQUIREMENTS FOR PUBLIC HOUSING AGENCIES. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will conduct a study to assess the efficiency of procurement procedures for public housing agencies in acquiring materials, labor, and services for public housing projects. The study will compare the current procurement system to a system where agencies can procure without following any federal requirements. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will review procurement policies of public housing agencies annually and may establish limitations on inappropriate policies or activities. The study will assess the advantages and disadvantages of different procurement systems for public housing agencies. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will conduct a study to determine the impact of labor standards on the affordability of public housing units. A report with findings and recommendations must be submitted to Congress within 2 years of the enactment of this Act.
